choices.text: Secretory, Menstrual
Menstrual, Proliferative
Proliferative, Secretory
Late secretory, Proliferative

questions.text: Images A and B, respectively, correspond to which of the following menstrual cycle phases:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proliferative, Secretory

 

  • In proliferative phase, the endometrial glands are short and non-tortuous.
  • In the secretory phase, the endometrial glands increase in size, become tortuous and with a subnuclear vacuole.
  • Menstrual phase endometrium appears fragmented in a background of blood

 

 

Thus Option C) Proliferative, Secretory is correct.

 

Educational Objective: Each phase (menstrual, proliferative, and secretory) exhibits distinct histological features that reflect the hormonal changes occurring during the cycle.  In the proliferative phase, the endometrial glands are short and non-tortuous, while in the secretory phase, the endometrial glands increase in size, become tortuous and with a subnuclear vacuole.

 

Ref: Page 356, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: It can be an insensitive test in many women
With ovulation, the temperature rises roughly 0.8°F
It is an inexpensive and easy test for ovulation monitoring
Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours

questions.text: Which of the following is LEAST likely true of basal body temperature testing in the adult female?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours

 

Explanation:

 

  • Basal body temperature (BBT) charting has long been used to identify ovulation.
  • This test requires that a woman’s morning oral temperature be graphically charted
  • Oral temperatures are usually 97.0° to 98.0°F during the follicular phase.
  • A postovulatory rise in progesterone levels increases basal temperature by approximately 0.4° to 0.8°F.
  • This biphasic temperature pattern is strongly predictive of ovulation.
  • Nevertheless, although this test has the advantage of being inexpensive, it is insensitive in many women.

 

 

Let's examine each statement:

 

Option A. It can be an insensitive test in many women: This is true. The temperature shift indicating ovulation can be subtle and easy to miss, and factors like illness, sleep disturbances, and lifestyle factors can affect temperature readings.

 

Option B. With ovulation, the temperature rises roughly 0.8°F: This is generally true. After ovulation, the release of progesterone causes a woman's basal body temperature to rise by approximately 0.4 to 0.8 degrees Fahrenheit. However, the exact increase can vary from woman to woman.

 

Option C. It is an inexpensive and easy test for ovulation monitoring: This is true. BBT charting is a cost-effective, non-invasive method of possibly determining ovulation. It requires only a thermometer and consistent daily temperature recording upon waking.

 

Option D. Once the temperature rises, a patient should expect ovulation in the next 12 hours (Least Likely True): This statement is incorrect. In fact, a rise in BBT typically occurs after ovulation. By the time a woman notices a temperature rise, ovulation has likely already occurred, not that it will occur in the next 12 hours.

 

Educational Objective: BBT charting can provide a retrospective confirmation of ovulation based on a temperature rise after ovulation has occurred.

 

Ref: Page no 435, Wiliams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: It affects approximately 50% of menstrual cycles
It is seen when the follicular phase is shorter than 14 days
Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women
It is determined by histologic analysis of the endometrium and defined by a greater than 4-day discrepancy between the specimen-derived cycle date and the actual menstrual cycle day

questions.text: Which of the following is true of luteal phase deficiency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women

 

Explanation:

 

  • LPD is a clinical diagnosis and may be present with a luteal phase ≤10 days in length.
  • Abnormal luteal function may occur as the result of several medical conditions.
  • True isolated LPD implies an underlying pathologic abnormality of the luteal phase in the absence of an identifiable disease process negatively affecting normal LH support of the corpus luteum.
  • No diagnostic test for LPD has proven to be reliable in the clinical setting or in differentiating fertile from infertile women.
  • Endometrial biopsies (lag of > 2 days) only have the precision to distinguish the early luteal, midluteal, and late luteal phases, and have been shown to not discriminate between fertile and infertile women.

 

Let's evaluate each statement:

 

Option A. It affects approximately 50% of menstrual cycles: This is not accurate. LPD does not affect such a high percentage of menstrual cycles. It is considered relatively less common and not observed in half of all menstrual cycles.

 

Option B. It is seen when the follicular phase is shorter than 14 days: LPD is related to the luteal phase, not the follicular phase. LPD is characterized by a luteal phase that is typically shorter than normal (less than about 10 days) or functionally inadequate.

 

Option C. Fertile women have the same incidence of luteal phase deficiency as infertile women (Correct Answer): Recent studies and reviews suggest that the incidence of LPD is similar in both fertile and infertile women. This challenges previous notions that LPD is a common cause of infertility. It's now understood that the diagnostic criteria for LPD may be overly broad, and the condition might not be as directly linked to infertility as once thought.

 

Option D. It is determined by histologic analysis of the endometrium and defined by a greater than 4-day discrepancy between the specimen-derived cycle date and the actual menstrual cycle day: This was the traditional method of diagnosing LPD, based on endometrial biopsy findings. However, the reliability of this diagnostic criterion has been questioned in recent years.

 

Educational Objective: LPD has traditionally been thought to be a cause of infertility, but recent studies suggest that its incidence in fertile women is similar to that in infertile women. The traditional method of diagnosing LPD through endometrial biopsy and histologic analysis has fallen out of favor due to its inherent limitations and the difficulty in accurately correlating histologic findings with the menstrual cycle phase.

 

Ref: Page no 434, Wiliams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: 2 million
7 million
1 thousand
300 thousand

questions.text: At the onset of puberty, what is the estimated number of follicles in a woman’s ovaries?
questions.solution:
Ans.D) 300 thousand

 

Explanation:

 

 

At the onset of puberty, a woman has about 300,000 to 400,000 follicles remaining in her ovaries. This number represents a significant reduction from the count at birth due to ongoing follicular atresia.

 

Educational Objective: It's crucial to recognize that the number of ovarian follicles a woman has is finite and decreases with age, a process that is marked by significant changes at various life stages, including puberty. At the onset of puberty, a woman has about 300,000 to 400,000 follicles .

 

Ref: Page no 319, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Anti-Mullerian hormone
Clomiphene citrate challenge test
Day 2 FSH
Day 15 Antral Follicle Count

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a test of ovarian reserve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Day 15 Antral Follicle Count

 

Explanation:

 

Tests for ovarian reserve include

 

  1. Biochemical tests
    • FSH: D2/3: Increased in poor ovarian reserve
    • Estradiol: Day 2: Increased in poor ovarian reserve 
    • Inhibin B: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
    • AMH: Reduced in poor ovarian reserve
  2. Ultrasound: Antral follicle count is done on day 2 or 3 of the cycle. The total no of follicles visible are counted. An AFC > 10 is normal.
  3. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test

 

Let's explore each option:

 

Option A. Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH): AMH is a hormone produced by the granulosa cells of small ovarian follicles. It is a reliable indicator of a woman's ovarian reserve, as it reflects the number of remaining antral and pre-antral follicles in the ovaries. AMH levels typically decrease with age and lower levels are associated with a diminished ovarian reserve.

 

Option B. Clomiphene Citrate Challenge Test: This test involves administering clomiphene citrate, a medication that stimulates ovulation, and measuring the response of the ovaries. The response is typically assessed through changes in follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) levels. Abnormal test results can suggest reduced ovarian reserve.

 

Option C. Day 2 FSH: This test measures the level of FSH in a woman's blood on the second day of her menstrual cycle. FSH is a hormone that stimulates the ovaries to produce eggs. Elevated levels of FSH on day 2 can be indicative of a diminished ovarian reserve, as the body is having to work harder to stimulate the ovaries.

 

Option D. Day 15 Antral Follicle Count (Correct Answer): This is not a standard test for ovarian reserve. The antral follicle count (AFC) is typically performed much earlier in the menstrual cycle, generally on day 2-5. The AFC involves counting the number of antral follicles (small follicles) in the ovaries using ultrasound, which can give an estimate of the remaining egg supply. Performing this count on day 15 would not be standard practice, as this is typically after ovulation has occurred, making it less relevant for assessing ovarian reserve.

 

Educational Objective: AMH levels, day 2 AFC, day 2 FSH and the clomiphene citrate challenge test are ovarian reserve tests and  offer unique insights into ovarian function.

 

Ref: Page 437, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: To determine the viability of sperm
To assess the quality of cervical mucous
To evaluate the process of ovulation
To examine the uterine lining

questions.text: An infertile couple is being evaluated for infertility. They are advised to take a post coital test. What is the purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess the quality of cervical mucous

 

Explanation:

 

  • The postcoital test, also known as the Sims-Huhner test, was used historically to evaluate cervical mucus.
  • There is limited consensus on the definition of a normal test and hence it does not have much utility. In regions where more specific testing is not available, it may provide information regarding cervical mucus, appropriate intercourse practices and sperm motility.
  • Performed a few hours after sexual intercourse
  • During the test, a sample of cervical mucous is collected using a speculum and a small brush and examined under a microscope to assess the quality, quantity and motility of sperm present in the mucus
  • This provides information about the interaction between the sperm and cervical mucus, which is crucial for successful fertilization.

 

Now, Let's explore each of the given options for its purpose:

 

Option A. To determine the viability of sperm: The test observes how sperm interact with cervical mucus, which encompasses more than just viability.

 

Option B. To assess the quality of cervical mucus (Correct Answer): This is the primary purpose of the postcoital test. It evaluates how well sperm can survive and move through the cervical mucus. This is important because cervical mucus changes in consistency and composition throughout the menstrual cycle, and these changes can impact sperm survival and transport. The test is usually conducted close to the time of ovulation when the cervical mucus is most receptive to sperm.

 

Option C. To evaluate the process of ovulation: While the timing of the postcoital test is related to ovulation (as it should be performed around the time of ovulation for optimal cervical mucus quality), the test itself does not evaluate ovulation directly.

 

Option D. To examine the uterine lining: The postcoital test does not assess the uterine lining. Procedures like ultrasound or endometrial biopsy are more relevant for examining the uterine lining.

 

Educational Objective: The primary educational objective of understanding the postcoital test is to recognize its role in evaluating a key aspect of fertility: the interaction between sperm and cervical mucus. This test helps to identify issues related to cervical factors in infertility, such as hostile cervical mucus that may impede sperm motility or survival.

 

Ref: Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Day 21 progesterone
Pre-menstrual endometrial biopsy
Serial transvaginal scans
Urinary FSH

questions.text: A 29-year woman presents to the Gyn OPD wit her husband. She has been unsuccessfully trying to conceive since 1.5 years. On asking, she reveals that she has irregular menstrual cycles. There is no other significant history. Which of the following is NOT a test for determining if she is ovulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Urinary FSH

 

Explanation:

 

Tests for Ovulation include

 

  1. History: Regular menstrual cycles; Mittelschmerz, dysmenorrhoea, Premenstrual Syndrome
  2. Basal body temperature: Just prior to ovulation, there is a drop in temperature by 0.25, then it rises by 0.5 deg C
  3. Cervical mucus study: At the time of ovulation, cervical mucus is thin and stretchy; It is thin and viscous at the time of luteal phase 
  4. Hormonal Studies:
    1. Mid Luteal Progesterone: Peak on Day 21 (> 10 ng/ml)
    2. Urinary LH kits 
  5. Endometrial Biopsy (Secretory phase of the cycle at day 21)
  6. Ultrasound:
  • Trilaminar endometrium seen in the proliferative phase.
  • In the secretory phase, the endometrium becomes homogeneous.
  • Ovary: Shows a dominant follicle at the time of ovulation (18-20 mm)
  1. Laparoscopy: If performed mid-cycle, a large follicle may be seen

 

Let's review each option:

 

Option A. Day 21 Progesterone: This test is used to confirm ovulation. Progesterone levels rise following ovulation, due to the formation of the corpus luteum. A blood test for progesterone is typically done about 7 days after expected ovulation (around day 21 in a typical 28-day cycle) to check if the levels are high enough to suggest that ovulation has occurred.

 

Option B. Pre-menstrual Endometrial Biopsy: This procedure involves taking a small sample of the uterine lining just before menstruation. It's used to check for luteal phase defects. The endometrium undergoes specific changes after ovulation, and analyzing the tissue can help determine if these changes are occurring properly, suggesting that ovulation has taken place.

 

Option C. Serial Transvaginal Scans: These are ultrasounds done transvaginally at different stages of the menstrual cycle. They can be used to monitor the growth and development of follicles in the ovaries, and to observe the rupture of a follicle (indicative of ovulation). This is a direct metho d to visualize the process of ovulation.

 

Option D. Urinary FSH (Correct Answer): Urinary FSH (Follicle Stimulating Hormone) levels are not typically used to determine if ovulation is occurring. FSH is important in the development of follicles in the ovaries, but its level in urine isn't directly correlated with ovulation. Blood levels of FSH are often measured, but usually to assess ovarian reserve rather than to confirm ovulation.

 

Educational Objective: Tests like day 21 progesterone, pre-menstrual endometrial biopsy, and serial transvaginal scans are used to confirm ovulation or assess the health of the luteal phase. Urinary FSH, on the other hand, is not a standard test for confirming ovulation however urinary LH kits may be used.

 

Ref: Page 435, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Pelvic ultrasound
HSG
Examination of male partner
Explain fertile period

questions.text: A 23-year woman is brought to the OPD by her mother-in-law who is very anxious that she hasn’t conceived since her marriage which was 8 months ago. The woman has regular cycles and coital frequency is about 3 times/ week. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Explain fertile period

 

Explanation:

 

  • As the woman is young and has no significant history, the best management would be reassurance with advice to follow up after 4 more months if she doesn’t conceive.
  • Evaluation for infertility is started after 1 year of unprotected intercourse or earlier if the woman is > 35 years or has irregular cycles.

 

Let's evaluate each option:

 

Option A. Pelvic Ultrasound: This imaging test can be useful to assess the uterus and ovaries for any structural abnormalities. However, without any specific symptoms or history suggesting a problem (such as irregular periods, pain, or a history of pelvic disease), jumping to a pelvic ultrasound might be premature at this stage.

 

Option B. Hysterosalpingography (HSG): HSG is used to evaluate the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's an important test in the fertility workup, it's usually not the first step, especially in a young woman without a significant duration of infertility (generally considered to be one year of trying without conception for women under 35).

 

Option C. Examination of Male Partner: Male factor infertility contributes to around half of all infertility cases. However, starting with the examination of the male partner without first addressing potential misunderstandings about the timing of intercourse relative to the fertile window may not be the most efficient first step.

 

Option D. Explain Fertile Period (Correct Answer): Since the couple has only been trying to conceive for 8 months, and the woman has regular cycles and there are no immediate indications of infertility, the most appropriate next step is to ensure that they have accurate information about the fertile window in the menstrual cycle. Understanding the timing of ovulation and the days during which conception is most likely can significantly increase the chances of natural conception.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Before proceeding any investigations, it's crucial to ensure that couples are aware of the most fertile period in the menstrual cycle, typically the days leading up to and including the day of ovulation.
  •  This knowledge is fundamental for any couple trying to conceive and is especially pertinent when the duration of trying is less than a year and there are no obvious symptoms or history suggesting infertility.

 

ReF: Page no 430, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Serum FSH
Serum LH
Urine LH
Urine FSH

questions.text: 22-year-old woman is anxious to conceive and is recently married since a few months. Her menstrual cycle ranges from 30-35 days. She explained the fertile period. In addition, which test will help her determine when she is ovulating?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Urine LH

 

Explanation: 

 

Tests for Ovulation are:

 

  • Basal body temperature
    • Progesterone causes an increase in 0.5 - 1°F
    • Inexpensive
    • Limitation: It is a retrospective diagnosis
  • Cervical mucus
    • Under the influence of progesterone, the cervical mucous becomes thick and sticky called “Spinnbarkeit”
  • LH monitoring
    • 2 hours following serum LH surge, urinary LH is detected
    • Commercially available urinary LH kits can detect urinary LH by ELISA
    • Once LH surge detected; ovulation occurs within 48 h
  • Midluteal serum Progesterone
    • Done on Day 21; >10 ng/ml – confirms ovulation
  • Transvaginal ultrasound
    • Serial scans from Day 10; Dominant follicle when it is 18-20 mm
  • Endometrial biopsy
    • Secretory changes in the endometrium indicate ovulation
    • Done between Day 24-28
    • Invasive so not preferred

 

Let's review each option separately:

 

Option A. Serum FSH: Follicle-stimulating hormone is important for the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles. While FSH levels rise at the beginning of the menstrual cycle, they are not typically used to predict ovulation .

 

Option B. Serum LH: Luteinizing hormone surges in the bloodstream just before ovulation, triggering the release of a mature egg from the ovary. Measuring serum LH can indicate impending ovulation, but blood tests are not as practical for routine ovulation tracking.

 

Option C. Urine LH (Correct Answer): Urine LH tests, often known as ovulation predictor kits  are a practical and widely used method to detect the surge in LH that precedes ovulation by about 24-36 hours. These home tests are user-friendly and allow women to track their most fertile days with good accuracy.

 

Option D. Urine FSH: Similar to serum FSH, urine FSH is not typically used to predict ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The use of ovulation predictor kits that measure LH in urine is a practical and effective method for women to identify their fertile window.

 

Ref: Page no 1150, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology, 15th edition
